thread.title: NAACP Invades Sen. Jeff Sessions’ Office, Refuses to Leave Until He Withdraws or They’re Arrested
thread.title_full: NAACP Invades Sen. Jeff Sessions’ Office, Refuses to Leave Until He Withdraws or They’re Arrested

author: Kim Smith
title: NAACP Invades Sen. Jeff Sessions’ Office, Refuses to Leave Until He Withdraws or They’re Arrested

organizations.name: gop senators announce measures to move u.s. embassy

text:
GOP Senators Announce Measures to Move U.S. Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem 
CNN reported that five men and one woman, including NAACP president Cornell Brooks, faced charges of criminal trespass, according to Mobile police. 
“We are doing this as an act of civil disobedience standing in the tradition of Rosa Parks and members of the NAACP community,” Brooks said, according to The New York Times . 
The Times reported that almost two dozen activists occupied the office around 11 a.m., condemning the senator’s “hostile” attitude toward civil rights.   
Brooks posted a photo of the sit-in to Twitter. The @NAACP & @AlabamaNAACP are occupying the Mobile office of @jeffsessions –untill he withdraws as a AG nominee or we're arrested. @tvonetv pic.twitter.com/7uceDDpz1Y 
— Cornell Wm. Brooks (@CornellWBrooks) January 3, 2017 
Lee Hedgepeth, a journalist, also posted a video of police escorting protesters out of the building around 6:30 p.m. 
Posted by Lee Hedgepeth on Tuesday, January 3, 2017 
Sarah Isgur Flores, Sessions’ confirmation spokeswoman, told the Washington Examiner that Sessions had dedicated his career to upholding the rule of law.
